H0.text: Evaporation is the process that occurs when glacial ice—slow‑moving sheets of ice found on land—is heated to 5° Celsius.

H1.text: Freezing is the process that occurs when glacial ice, a slow‑moving sheet of ice found on land, is heated to 5 °C.

H2.text: Melting is the process that occurs when glacial ice—slow‑moving sheets of ice found on land—is heated to 5 °C.

H3.text: Precipitation is the process that occurs when glacial ice, a slow‑moving sheet of ice found on land, is heated to 5 °C.

A4.text: The most common phase transition to ice Ih occurs when liquid water is cooled below 0 °C (273.15 K, 32 °F) at standard atmospheric pressure.

A5.text: When ice melts it absorbs as much energy as would be required to heat an equivalent mass of water by 80 °C.
